fields.object_repr: Starting a Ruby on Rails app - jsmith
Getting certified - AWS Certified Cloud Practitioner - jsmith

fields.title: Starting a Django project
fields.intro: Properly setting up a Django project.
fields.body:
## Install Python

The version we are going to use is `3.11`.  
I am on a Mac so I will use homebrew to install Python:

```sh
‚ùØ brew install python@3.10
```

Let's check that Python version we want to use is installed:

```sh
‚ùØ python3.11 --version
Python 3.11.0

‚ùØ python3.11
Python 3.11.0 (main, Oct 26 2022, 19:06:18) [Clang 14.0.0 (clang-1400.0.29.202)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>>
```


## Create the folder for the project

I usually put my coding projects inside a folder located at `~/Sites`.  

Let's create the **test_project** folder and cd into it:

```sh
~/Sites
‚ùØ mkdir test_project

~/Sites
‚ùØ cd test_project

~/Sites/test_project
‚ùØ pwd
/Users/cloudcruder/Sites/test_project
```


## Creating the virtual environment

First of all, verify that you are into the correct folder, make sure that you are into the **test_project** folder.

```sh
‚ùØ python3.11 -m venv .venv
```

Here you are telling python to create a virtual environment using Python version 3.10 in a folder called **.venv**.

Then activate that environment:

```sh
‚ùØ source .venv/bin/activate
```

To check that the project is using the python version of your virtual environment:

```sh
‚ùØ which python
/Users/cloudcruder/Sites/test_project/.venv/bin/python
```


## Installing packages

Check that the package manager does not require an update:

```sh
‚ùØ pip install --upgrade pip
```


### Install Django

```sh
‚ùØ pip install django
```

Verify that Django is properly installed:

```sh
‚ùØ python -m django --version
4.1.4
```

```sh
‚ùØ pip freeze > requirements.txt
```

This file will come in handy when reinstalling your project.


### Create Django project

```sh
‚ùØ django-admin startproject test_project
```

Now inside of the folder **test_project** you have another folder called **test_project**:

```sh
~/Sites/test_project via üêç v3.10.8 (.venv)
‚ùØ ls -la
total 8
drwxr-xr-x   5 cloudcruder  staff  160 Dec  7 14:58 .
drwxr-xr-x  11 cloudcruder  staff  352 Dec  7 14:30 ..
drwxr-xr-x   6 cloudcruder  staff  192 Dec  7 14:32 .venv
-rw-r--r--   1 cloudcruder  staff   45 Dec  7 14:35 requirements.txt
drwxr-xr-x   4 cloudcruder  staff  128 Dec  7 14:58 test_project
```

And, if you cd into that last  **test_project** you will have another  **test_project** folder:

```sh
~/Sites/test_project via üêç v3.10.8 (.venv)
‚ùØ cd test_project

Sites/test_project/test_project via üêç v3.10.8 (.venv)
‚ùØ ls -la
total 8
drwxr-xr-x  4 cloudcruder  staff  128 Dec  7 14:58 .
drwxr-xr-x  5 cloudcruder  staff  160 Dec  7 14:58 ..
-rwxr-xr-x  1 cloudcruder  staff  668 Dec  7 14:58 manage.py
drwxr-xr-x  7 cloudcruder  staff  224 Dec  7 14:58 test_project
```

Not ideal. So, rename the second  **test_project** folder to **src**, you should now have:
**test_project** > **src** > **test_project**


### Start the server

Make sure you are into the **src** directory, then:

```sh
~/Sites/test_project via üêç v3.10.8 (.venv)
‚ùØ cd src

Sites/test_project/src via üêç v3.10.8 (.venv)
‚ùØ ls -la
total 8
drwxr-xr-x  4 cloudcruder  staff  128 Dec  7 14:58 .
drwxr-xr-x  5 cloudcruder  staff  160 Dec  7 15:04 ..
-rwxr-xr-x  1 cloudcruder  staff  668 Dec  7 14:58 manage.py
drwxr-xr-x  7 cloudcruder  staff  224 Dec  7 14:58 test_project
```

Then run:

```sh
‚ùØ python manage.py runserver
```


## Migrations

### Show which migrations are awaiting

Make sure you are into the **src** directory, then:

```sh
‚ùØ python manage.py showmigrations
```


### Make migration

If you created a model in one of your apps, you need to tell Django to make those migrations first before you'll be able to see and run them.

```sh
‚ùØ python manage.py makemigrations
```

### Run migrations

Make sure you are into the **src** directory, then:

```sh
‚ùØ python manage.py migrate
```


## Admin

### Create super user

Make sure you are into the **src** directory, then:

```sh
‚ùØ python manage.py createsuperuser
```

Follow the prompt & provide the informations required.  
Now you can go to `http://127.0.0.1:8000/admin` and login with the user you just created.


## Notes

‚ö†Ô∏è When running migration commands, make sure that the app for which the migration is for is listed in `INSTALLED_APS` in the project's settings file.

fields.title: Starting a Ruby on Rails app
fields.intro: Properly setting up a Ruby on Rails project.
fields.body:
## Setting up the dev environment I am working on a MacOS device but the setup should be fairly identic if you are on any Linux distro. I assume you have [homebrew](https://brew.sh/) installed. ### Install Rbenv and Ruby I use [rbenv](https://github.com/rbenv/rbenv), as my Ruby versions manager ```sh ‚ùØ brew install rbenv ``` Don't forget to add the line bellow in you bashrc or zshrc, I am using the latter since it is the default on Mac. ```txt if which rbenv > /dev/null; then eval "$(rbenv init -)"; fi ``` And source the zshrc: ```sh ‚ùØ source ~/.zshrc ``` Or just close the terminal and open a new one. Install the ruby version you want to use, I am going to use version `3.1.2`: ```sh ‚ùØ rbenv install 3.1.2 ``` Let's check that the version 3.1.2 is installed: ```sh ‚ùØ rbenv versions * system 3.1.2 ``` Here you listed all the ruby versions installed on your computer. The current global version is the system one, not the one you just installed. Let's change that: ```sh ‚ùØ rbenv global 3.1.2 ``` Now if you check the rbenv versions again:‚ö†Ô∏è ```sh ‚ùØ rbenv versions system * 3.1.2 (set by /Users/user_name/.rbenv/version) ``` #### Install a gem Let's install a gem to make sure the ruby version we try to use is working fine. ```sh ‚ùØ gem install foreman Successfully installed foreman-0.87.2 1 gem installed ``` We will need Foreman to run the Procfile. #### Gem installations gotchas üìù In case you have the error bellow: ```sh WARNING: You don't have /home/user_name/.gem/ruby/3.1.2/bin in your PATH, gem executables will not run. ``` Add in your `.zshrc` file: ```text PATH="`ruby -e 'puts Gem.user_dir'`/bin:$PATH" ``` Source your `.zshrc` then try again. üôÇ ### NVM and NodeJS Install nvm for managing NodeJS versions. ```sh ‚ùØ brew install nvm ``` Let's install the latest LTS version: ```sh ‚ùØ nvm install --lts ``` Or ```sh ‚ùØ nvm install 16.14.2 ``` if you want a specific versions. Install Yarn globally. ```sh ‚ùØ npm install --global yarn ``` ### Postgresql ```sh ‚ùØ brew install postgresql ``` After the installation don't forget to run: ```sh ‚ùØ brew services restart postgresql ``` ### Redis ```sh ‚ùØ brew install redis ``` ## Creating the Rails project
  • Testing: Rspec
  • Authentication: Devise
### Ruby version for project is the same as global one I usually put my coding projects inside a folder located at `~/Sites`. ```sh ‚ùØ ruby --version ruby 3.1.2p20 (2022-04-12 revision 4491bb740a) [arm64-darwin22] ``` If the global ruby version is the one we want to use for our project: Install the rails gem: ```sh ‚ùØ gem install rails ``` And generate the rails project: ```sh ‚ùØ rails new name_of_the_app --database=postgresql --skip-jbuilder --skip-test --css=tailwind --javascript=esbuild ``` ### Ruby version for the project is different of global one If the ruby version you want to use for your project is different from the ruby version set as the global version on you computer: First cd into `~/Sites`, then we create the folder for our project: ```sh ‚ùØ mkdir my_app_name ``` Then cd into `my_app_name` folder and set the local version to the one you want, here we are using `3.1.2`: ```sh ‚ùØ rbenv local 3.1.2 ``` Then generate the rails project: ```sh ‚ùØ rails new . --database=postgresql --skip-jbuilder --skip-test --css=tailwind --javascript=esbuild ``` ## Testing ### Rspec Add Rspec in development and test group of the Gemfile: ```sh group :development, :test do gem "rspec-rails", "~> 6.0.0" end ``` Run ```sh ‚ùØ bundle install ``` Then ```sh ‚ùØ rails generate rspec:install ‚ùØ bundle binstubs rspec-core ``` The last command allows us to use a shourtcut when running our tests, that command is: ```sh ‚ùØ bin/rspec No examples found. Finished in 0.00014 seconds (files took 0.05266 seconds to load) 0 examples, 0 failures ``` No tests, no issues. üòÇüôà #### Test helpers ##### Where to find the files Uncomment the line below in `spec/rails_helper.rb` ```ruby Dir[Rails.root.join('spec', 'support', '**', '*.rb')].sort.each { |f| require f } ``` This tells Rspec where to load the helper files it needs for our tests. ##### Rspec configuration for helpers Configuration update for other modules such as ActiveJob, ActionMailbox, Devise...etc Inside of `RSpec.configure do |config|` block in `spec/rails_helper.rb` file add: ``` config.global_fixtures = :all config.include ActiveJob::TestHelper config.include ActionMailbox::TestHelper # config.include Devise::Test::IntegrationHelpers, type: :feature # config.include Devise::Test::ControllerHelpers, type: :controller ``` The `config.global_fixtures = :all` tells rails to load all the fixtures created as test data. We leave the configurations for Devise helpers commented for now, we will update them when we add Devise into our app. ##### Helpers for requests Add a new folder called `support` in `spec`. Then create a file named `request_spec_helper.rb`. Or just run: ``` ¬©mkdir -p spec/support/request_spec_helper.rb ``` In `spec/support/request_spec_helper.rb` add: ```ruby module RequestSpecHelper include Warden::Test::Helpers def self.included(base) base.before(:each) { Warden.test_mode! } base.after(:each) { Warden.test_reset! } end def sign_in(resource) login_as(resource, scope: warden_scope(resource)) resource end def sign_out(resource) logout(warden_scope(resource)) end def json JSON.parse(response.body).with_indifferent_access end private def warden_scope(resource) resource.class.name.underscore.to_sym end end RSpec.configure do |config| config.include RequestSpecHelper, type: :request config.before(:each, type: :request) { host! "my_app.test" } end ``` This file essentially tells Devise to put itself into test mode to handle login requests while we run our tests. It also gives us helpers for testing login and logout for users in tests. #### Generators When we use the rails genarator it tends to create files that most of the time we end up deleting. To prevent that, let's tweak the `config/application.rb` file: First remove the following lines: ```ruby # Don't generate system test files. config.generators.system_tests = nil ``` Then ```ruby config.generators do |g| g.skip_routes true g.helper false g.assets false g.test_framework :rspec, fixture: false g.helper_specs false g.controller_specs false g.system_tests false g.view_specs false end # GZip all responses config.middleware.use Rack::Deflater ``` The last line zips the responses, which is useful if we don't use ngnix when we deploy our app. ## Authentication: Devise In our `Gemfile` add devise in the general section: ```text # Flexible authentication solution for Rails with Warden (https://github.com/heartcombo/devise) gem "devise", "~> 4.8" ``` And in the development section of our `Gemfile` add: ```text group :development do # Preview mail in browser instead of sending. (https://github.com/ryanb/letter_opener) gem "letter_opener", "~> 1.8.1" end ``` Now let's install those gems: ```sh ‚ùØ bundle install ``` ### Configure Devise #### Specify the layout we want to use for Devise Open `config/application.rb` and add: ```ruby config.to_prepare do Devise::SessionsController.layout "auth" # DeviseInvitable::RegistrationsController.layout "auth" # Devise::InvitationsController.layout "auth" Devise::RegistrationsController.layout "auth" Devise::ConfirmationsController.layout "auth" Devise::UnlocksController.layout "auth" Devise::PasswordsController.layout "auth" Devise::Mailer.layout "mailer" end ``` #### Routes related config for Devise Open `app/controllers/application_controller.rb` and add the code below to protect all routes by default and allow some extra params: ```ruby before_action :configure_permitted_parameters, if: :devise_controller? before_action :authenticate_user! protected def configure_permitted_parameters devise_parameter_sanitizer.permit(:sign_up, keys: %i[first_name last_name terms_and_conditions]) devise_parameter_sanitizer.permit(:account_update, keys: %i[first_name last_name]) end ``` Here we tell Devise to add `first_nam`, `last_name`, `terms_and_conditions` fields on the signup form otherwise Devise only asks for the `email` field. We also tell devise to protect all our pages, i.e requiring user to be authenticated in order to access the pages, thanks to this line of code: ```ruby before_action :authenticate_user! ``` If we want to override that for a specific page we replace it with: ```ruby skip_before_action :authenticate_user!, only: [:show] ``` The `, only: [:show]` part can be ommited if you have no action where you want to skip it. #### Generate devise & create first model We installed the Devise gem, now lets run the generator for the necessary files to configure it: ```text ‚ùØ rails generate devise:install create config/initializers/devise.rb create config/locales/devise.en.yml =============================================================================== =============================================================================== Depending on your application's configuration some manual setup may be required: 1. Ensure you have defined default url options in your environments files. Here is an example of default_url_options appropriate for a development environment in config/environments/development.rb: config.action_mailer.default_url_options = { host: 'localhost', port: 3000 } In production, :host should be set to the actual host of your application. * Required for all applications. * 2. Ensure you have defined root_url to *something* in your config/routes.rb. For example: root to: "home#index" * Not required for API-only Applications * 3. Ensure you have flash messages in app/views/layouts/application.html.erb. For example:

<%= notice %>

<%= alert %>

* Not required for API-only Applications * 4. You can copy Devise views (for customization) to your app by running: rails g devise:views * Not required * =============================================================================== ... ``` We are suggested to make 4 changes: * For the first one, add that line in `config/environments/development.rb` * For the second, let's create a page controller in `app/controllers/website/pages_controller.r` and add a methode for the homepage: ```ruby # frozen_string_literal: true class Website::PagesController < ApplicationController layout "website" skip_before_action :authenticate_user! def homepage; end end ``` We use a specific layout for this section Update `app/views/layouts/application.html.erb` with what is suggested in the 3rd recommandation. Now let's use the updated application layout to create the one we want to use with Devise: ```sh cp app/views/layouts/application.html.erb app/views/layouts/auth.html.erb ``` ```sh ‚ùØ rails generate devise User ```

fields.title: Docker Docker Docker
fields.intro: What is docker? Why docker? How to create an image and host it?
fields.body:
## What is it? Why use it?

Docker is language agnostic, whatever language you use to write your app it will run in a docker container.   
The container created by Docker provides a minimal environment for whatever you want to run without the 
interference hosting system.

What docker does is take your source code and build it into an image container.

To build the image you require a series of instructions, a set of steps for docker to follow on how the container image 
should be.
```
Container Image = App code + Dependencies + Docker instructions
```

**Note**: a container image is not a full-blown OS. It is not a full Linux distro, just a Linux construct. 
The container uses the Kernel of the host it is running on.


## Dockerfile

`Dockerfile` is the document that lists the instructions to follow in order to build the container image.

As an example lets build a linux base NodeJS app. So, in the dockerfile you will have:
```dockerfile
FROM node:18.12.1-alpine3.15
```
In a Dockerfile the first line is the FROM statement, it specifies what to use in order to build the image :
* grab the specified NodeJS image version
* use that image to have NodeJS tools installed 
* use that image to form the bottom layer of the container


Let's have a look at the full dockerfile with comments explaining what each line/instruction does:
```dockerfile
FROM node:18.12.1-alpine3.15

LABEL org.opencontainers.image.title="Workstation Docker Image" \
      org.opencontainers.image.description="Web server showing host that responded" \
      org.opencontainers.image.authors="@cloudcruder"

# Create directory in container image for app code
RUN mkdir -p /usr/src/app

# Copy app code (.) to /usr/src/app in container image
COPY . /usr/src/app

# Set working directory context
WORKDIR /usr/src/app

# Install dependencies from packages.json
RUN npm install

# Command for container to execute, will be run each time the container is run  
ENTRYPOINT [ "node", "server/app.js" ]
```

`RUN mkdir -p /usr/src/app` tells docker to create a folder. The `-p` flag allows to create nested folders.

`COPY . /usr/src/app` tells docker to copy everything on the same level as the `Dockerfile` into `/usr/src/app`.


## Images


### Build images

The command for building an image is `$ docker image build .`.

You can add a tag after the build command:  
`$ docker image build -t your-docker-id/name-of-the-repo:name-of-the-image .`.  
The `name-of-the-image` part can be a version string if you really need to keep track of the version for each build.  
The `.` at the end indicates to Docker where all the files that it needs are.

`$ docker image build -t cloudcruder/workstation:base-app .`


### List images

Now if you run `$ docker image list` or `$ docker image ls`
```
‚ùØ docker image ls
REPOSITORY        TAG               IMAGE ID       CREATED         SIZE
<none>            <none>            e374d6058a3e   6 minutes ago   201MB
sample-app        latest            aab3497ef956   3 days ago      112MB
```

The first line is the result of running the command `$ docker image build .`.  
Ther is no repository name nor tag.
```
REPOSITORY        TAG               IMAGE ID       CREATED         SIZE
<none>            <none>            e374d6058a3e   6 minutes ago   201MB
```

The second line is the result of running the command `$ docker image build .`.  
There is a repository name and a tag.
```
REPOSITORY                TAG               IMAGE ID       CREATED          SIZE
cloudcruder/workstation   base-app          e374d6058a3e   12 minutes ago   201MB
```


### Host images

First make sure you have an account on [dockerhub](https://hub.docker.com/).  
Also make sure you are logged in the Docker desktop application otherwise the push will be denied.

Then upload your image to "your registry":  
`$ docker image push your-docker-id/name-of-the-repo:name-of-the-image`.  
So for me it would be:  
`$ docker image push cloudcruder/workstation:base-app`

fields.title: Getting certified - AWS Certified Cloud Practitioner
fields.intro:
Build foundational knowledge about Cloud Computing.
Learn about AWS services and how they work together.
fields.body:
• Cloud Computing fundamentals
  • Technology tools and services
  • Security and compliance
  • Billing and pricing
# Cloud Computing fundamentals ## What is Cloud Computing? **Cloud Computing** is the on-demand delivery of compute power, database storage, applications, and other IT resources through a cloud services platform via the internet with pay-as-you-go-pricing thanks to data-centers that cloud computing providers manage. Examples of Cloud Computing providers: **AWS**, **Google Cloud Computing**, **Azure**. Examples of services provided by AWS per categories: * Compute: AWS EC2, Lambda * Networking: VPC, Direct Connect * Storage: S3, EBS * Analytics: Athena, Redshift * Development: Cloud9, CodeCommit * Security: IAM, Macie * Databases: RDS, DynamoDB ## Cloud Computing Models ## Cloud deployment Models **Servers**

Back to the top

# Technology tools and services

Back to the top

# Security and compliance

Back to the top

# Billing and pricing

Back to the top

# References [Overview of Amazon Web Services - AWS Whitepaper](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/pdfs/whitepapers/latest/aws-overview/aws-overview.pdf#introduction) (‚ùóÔ∏èRead once and read again juste before the exam.)
